issues.title: "backward compatibility to the conventional NS-based delegation "
issues.author: moonshiner
issues.body:
*  DELEG should allow for backward compatibility to the conventional NS-based delegation mechanism. 

I believe that should be a hard requirement. In fact, I think it should be the first hard requirement.

comments.author: moonshiner
comments.body: "DELEG may enhance existing namespace semantics, but only in ways that are backward compatible"

comments.author: vttale
comments.body: Between the wording proposed for the hard requirement in Issue #2 (or something similar) and the rest of that bullet item saying that this soft requirement was about being able to derive NS records from DELEG information, I think this is covered.

comments.author: vttale
comments.body: Addressed in 6bbb063216c0f1e7a4c827256489be95610f1ea3

issues.title: "current namespace semantics"
issues.author: moonshiner
issues.body:
Perhaps a hard requirement of:

The nameserver (NS) record type will continue to define the delegation of authority between a parent zone and a child zone with the existing semantics.

and a soft of

DELEG may enhance existing namespace semantics, but only in ways that are backward compatible.

comments.author: vttale
comments.body:
Proposed:
DELEG must be backwards compatible with the existing ecosystem. Legacy zone data must function identically with both DELEG-aware and DELEG-unaware software. Nameserver(NS)records will continue to define the delegation of authority between a parent zone and a child zone exactly as they have.

comments.author: vttale
comments.body: Addressed in 6bbb063216c0f1e7a4c827256489be95610f1ea3

issues.title: Must support multiple operators
issues.author: moonshiner
issues.body:
This may be a hard requirement that it must be possible to transition a domain between domain operators.

This may be a soft requirement to allow multiple simultaneous operators for a domain (eg, think what drives multi-provider DNSSEC as well as large enterprises that require vendor diversity for their authoritative zones).

comments.author: enygren
comments.body:
It sounds like this a single new hard requirement should be added here, along the lines of:

* DELEG MUST enable a zone to simultaneously have multiple independent operators.

(wordsmithing is most welcome)

comments.author: vttale
comments.body: I also wanted to say something like "DELEG must not make it harder to switch operators" but I don't think we can actually say something like that.  To the extent that a zone is using deleg with an operator that supports it, it would have an impact on their options for other operators.

issues.title: "enable a DNS operator to manage DNS service more completely on behalf of registrants"
issues.author: vttale
issues.body: Discussion in the chat during the deleg meeting suggested that maybe this was a little too meta about just what was meant, but it also wasn't clear that the actual content of the document was being replied to.  But maybe add another phrase at also being able to support operators being able to update the names of nameserver targets.

comments.author: vttale
comments.body:
Proposed:
   DELEG should enable a DNS operator to manage DNS service more
   completely on behalf of domain administrators. For example, DELEG
   could address long-standing issues of DNSSEC record maintenance
   that now often depend on registrant / registrar interaction.
   Similarly, DELEG could allow new transports to be deployed by an
   operator or nameserver names to be changed, without necessitating
   that delegation information be modified by the domain administrator.

comments.author: enygren
comments.body: Makes sense to me.

comments.author: moonshiner
comments.body: Is this hard or soft requirement?

comments.author: enygren
comments.body:
I think a hard requirement as otherwise it is a substantial regression
relative to today.


On Mon, Jul 22, 2024 at 4:08 PM Tim Wicinski ***@***.***>
wrote:

> Is this hard or soft requirement?
>
> —

comments.author: moonshiner
comments.body: agreed it should be a hard requirement.  just wanting it called out.

comments.author: vttale
comments.body: This comes from soft requirements because it is attempting to solve one of the existing problems.  It isn't a regression to not address it; it is the status quo to not address it.  (This is separate from the multiple operators issue, which is a hard requirement and would be a regression.)

comments.author: vttale
comments.body: Addressed in 71ec5c000efcec8cae28c70d003b24b0dbc385d5

issues.title: address deployability
issues.author: vttale
issues.body: At the meeting, some text on deployability was desired.  Especially to not require any sort of flag day.

issues.title: will NS be forever required or aim to be eventually dead
issues.author: vttale
issues.body: Maybe we need a section on "not a requirement" that this be addressed; that current work cannot really address whether future NS use is either mandatory not intended to be obsoleted

comments.author: moonshiner
comments.body:
can we define deleg requirements mentioning NS or DS records ? 
(or orthogonal)

comments.author: moonshiner
comments.body: paulh "the addition of DELEG records does not change that".

issues.title: We have Hard and Soft Requirements for backward compatability
issues.author: moonshiner
issues.body:
Hard 


   *  DELEG must be backwards compatible with the existing ecosystem.
      Legacy zone data must function identically with both DELEG-aware
      and DELEG-unaware software.  Nameserver (NS) records will continue
      to define the delegation of authority between a parent zone and a
      child zone exactly as they have.

Soft:

   *  DELEG should allow for backward compatibility to the conventional
      NS-based delegation mechanism.  That is, a Zone Operator who wants
      to maintain a single source of truth of delegation information
      using DELEG should be able to easily have Do53 delegations derived
      from it.

comments.author: moonshiner
comments.body: I think it is fine to have both but we wordsmithed the hard requirement and we should they don't overlap./

comments.author: vttale
comments.body: They are definitely two different things, which is why they appear separately.  The hard one is basically that NS records should keep working exactly as they have.  The soft is that NS configuration should be derivable from DELEG configuration.

issues.title: Address issue with client-side update
issues.author: moonshiner
issues.body:
Does seem to be addressed independently

per WG discussion

comments.author: vttale
comments.body:
It's in the doc because someone had brought it up as a wish list item, though I can't remember who.  Unlike Ben's comment to the list that it is "largely irrelevant", I do see it as relevant because it is talking about the relationship across the boundary of a delegation and is pretty closely related to existing issues like DS updates.

I brought the issue up during my presentation on the draft, where I called out that this could be solved with the proposal for DNS Notify.  As a soft requirement it is only aspirational so it doesn't fully matter if it isn't achieved, but it can also be explicitly addressed in any protocol design with a simple call out to DNS Notify and keeping the issue on the radar seems worthwhile to me.

I'm mostly in favor of keeping it in, but won't fight for it if the wind blows against it.

issues.title: Cfa Comments from Paul Wouters
issues.author: moonshiner
issues.body:
DELEG must be able to secure delegations with DNSSEC. Ideally it should
         be able to convey an even stronger security model for delegations than
         currently exists.

I don't understand this? What is an "even stronger security model" than DNSSEC ?

         DELEG must support updates to delegation information with the same
         relative ease as currently exists with NS records. Changes should
         take the same amount of time (eg, controlled by a DNS TTL) and
         allow a smooth transition between different operational platforms.

This seems to talk about DNS outside of the EPP/registration world? I thought
the goal was to be "easier" then going through EPP/webportals ? I
thought current "NS updating" is NOT "relative easy" (for a DNS provider
that is not also the Registrar) ?

         DELEG must be incrementally deployable and not require any sort
         of flag day of universal change to be effective.

can "to be effective" be removed? That makes the whole clause rather strange.

         DELEG should enable a DNS operator to manage DNS service more
         completely on behalf of domain administrators. For example, DELEG
         could address long-standing issues of DNSSEC record maintenance
         that now often depend on registrant / registrar interaction.

Should this not be a "hard requirement"?

comments.author: vttale
comments.body:
For the first one, the issue is that right now the records in a delegation are not signed.  Most of the discussion around a new method has included the notion that they would be signed, which is stronger.  I don't know that it needs more words in the document to clarify since it hasn't been brought up by others as confusing, but maybe just adding "where delegations are unsigned" after "currently exists" would be sufficient.

For "This seems to talk about DNS outside of the EPP/registration world" I'm not quite sure what the issue is here.   The requirement is simply that updating DELEG shouldn't be intrinsically harder than updating NS would be, via whatever mechanism is being used to do it.

I disagree that "to be effective" makes that sentence all that strange, but also don't think it's adding much and don't really care whether it stays or goes.

For the last thing, no I don't think it should be a hard requirement.  The doc is fairly clearly that the hard requirements are mostly about what we're avoiding breaking, and the soft requirements are about the problem space that is trying to be solved.

pulls.title: Address Issue 2 "existing semantics"
pulls.author: vttale
pulls.body: List discussion indicated that "must not change existing semantics" phrasing was ambiguous.  Clarify that it means that existing delegations would continue to work the same way.

comments.author: moonshiner
comments.body: This looks good

pulls.title: Issue 4: facilitate enhanced domain operations
pulls.author: vttale
pulls.body: Use the phrase "domain administrators" as a general term not specific to registrants, while still using registrants in the context of the current ICANN RRR model issue.  Add renaming nameservers as another example.

comments.author: moonshiner
comments.body: this looks good also

pulls.title: DELEG must allow multiple independent operators
pulls.author: vttale

comments.author: moonshiner
comments.body: Looks good.

pulls.title: Incrementally deployable and no flag day.
pulls.author: vttale
pulls.body: DELEG must be incrementally deployable and not require any sort of flag day of universal change to be effective.

comments.author: moonshiner
comments.body: Agreed - no flag day

pulls.title: not requirements
pulls.author: moonshiner
pulls.body:
Two non-requirements added, the future of NS and where deleg information is placed.

Placeholder for one more that is escaping me at the moment.
